title: Commonly Confused Words
description: Affect or effect? Complement or compliment? Test your knowledge of tricky word pairs!

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct word?
options: The weather will effect our plans.
The weather will affect our plans.
The weather will have no affect on us.
The affect of the storm was devastating.
questions.explanation: 'Affect' is a verb meaning to influence. 'Effect' is usually a noun meaning the result. The weather influences (affects) plans.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct word?
options: That scarf really compliments your outfit.
I received a lovely complement on my cooking.
That scarf really complements your outfit.
She gave me a nice complement about my hair.
questions.explanation: 'Complement' means to complete or go well with something. 'Compliment' means to praise. A scarf complements (goes well with) an outfit.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct word?
options: The principle of the school gave a speech.
She has strong principals.
The principal of the school gave a speech.
It's a matter of principal.
questions.explanation: 'Principal' refers to the head of a school or something of primary importance. 'Principle' means a fundamental truth or rule of conduct.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct word?
options: I need to buy some stationary for school.
The car remained stationery at the light.
The car remained stationary at the light.
I bought new stationary paper and pens.
questions.explanation: 'Stationary' means not moving. 'Stationery' refers to writing materials like paper and pens.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct word?
options: I'll except your apology.
Everyone accept Tom was invited.
Everyone except Tom was invited.
Please except this gift.
questions.explanation: 'Except' means excluding or leaving out. 'Accept' means to receive willingly. Everyone was invited, excluding (except) Tom.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct word?
options: Don't loose your keys.
The knot came lose.
I don't want to lose my keys.
My shoelaces are lose.
questions.explanation: 'Lose' is a verb meaning to misplace or be unable to find. 'Loose' is an adjective meaning not tight or free.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct word?
options: Their going to the store later.
They're going to the store later.
There going to the store later.
Theyre going to the store later.
questions.explanation: 'They're' is a contraction of 'they are.' 'Their' shows possession, and 'there' indicates a place.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct word?
options: Who's dog is that in the yard?
Whose the person in charge here?
Whose dog is that in the yard?
Who's book is on the table?
questions.explanation: 'Whose' is a possessive pronoun asking about ownership. 'Who's' is a contraction of 'who is' or 'who has.'

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct word?
options: There are less people here today.
I have fewer money than yesterday.
There are fewer people here today.
She has less friends than her sister.
questions.explanation: 'Fewer' is used for countable nouns (people, items). 'Less' is used for uncountable nouns (money, time, water).

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct word?
options: I'm going to lay down for a nap.
Please lie the book on the table.
I'm going to lie down for a nap.
The chicken lied three eggs.
questions.explanation: 'Lie' means to recline (no direct object). 'Lay' means to put something down (requires a direct object). You lie down, but you lay a book on a table.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct word?
options: Please insure all doors are locked.
I need to ensure my car against theft.
Please ensure all doors are locked.
Can you insure that the package arrives?
questions.explanation: 'Ensure' means to make certain something happens. 'Insure' means to arrange financial compensation in case of damage or loss.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct word?
options: Washington, D.C. is our nation's capitol.
The capitol of France is Paris.
The capital building has a large dome.
The capital of France is Paris.
questions.explanation: 'Capital' refers to a city that serves as the seat of government, or to wealth. 'Capitol' refers specifically to a building where a legislature meets.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct word?
options: I'll have chocolate cake for desert.
The Sahara Dessert is very hot.
The soldiers would never dessert their post.
I'll have chocolate cake for dessert.
questions.explanation: 'Dessert' (two s's) is a sweet treat after a meal. 'Desert' (one s) is a dry, barren landscape or means to abandon.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct word?
options: The comedian tried to illicit laughter.
The police uncovered illicit activities.
The survey was designed to illicit responses.
The elicit trade in wildlife is a problem.
questions.explanation: 'Illicit' is an adjective meaning illegal or forbidden. 'Elicit' is a verb meaning to draw out or evoke a response.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct word?
options: My grandparents emigrated to America from Italy.
Many people immigrate from the United States.
She emigrated to Canada from Mexico last year.
They plan to immigrate from the country soon.
questions.explanation: 'Emigrate' means to leave one's country to live elsewhere (emigrate FROM). 'Immigrate' means to come to a new country to live (immigrate TO).
